Abstract: Quantitative scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) has emerged as a powerful tool in materials science, offering unparalleled capabilities in imaging, diffraction, spectroscopy, and tomography. This review highlights recent advancements in STEM techniques, emphasizing the integration of quantitative analysis and simulation to enhance the accuracy and reliability of structural and compositional characterization. High-resolution imaging and diffraction methods enable the detailed examination of atomic arrangements, while spectroscopic techniques provide insights into chemical composition and electronic properties. Tomographic approaches further extend the capabilities by reconstructing three-dimensional structures, crucial for understanding complex materials. The synergy between experimental data and computational simulations is pivotal in validating and refining the quantitative interpretations. This comprehensive overview underscores the versatility and impact of STEM in advancing materials science research, facilitating the development of novel materials with tailored properties for various applications.
